column4: How do I remove the default home folder created by a Jaunty install? I set up fstab so ubuntu mounts /home on a different partition, but now how do I access and delete the default /home?
I'm pretty new. can you explain that in more detail?

On a previous install, I placed /home on its own partition, sda6. When I reinstalled, I left that partition alone, and after the install I set up fstab to mount sda6 as /home. that's the home folder I'm using now. I'm not sure even how to find the default home directory created during the install.
do you understand what I'm doing?
default home is hiddem because of partition mounted at /home/
How do I unmount that partition if it's the home folder I'm using?
logout, and log in as root in the terminal
sudo passwd root, type password you want, logoud, switch to tty1, login as root and umount /home
does it actually matter if the default home directory is there?
or you can set up user directory somewhere else with usermod
or just remove /home partition from fstab

fosco__: thanks for the suggestions. Unfortunately I have to be careful about thinking on my own. I'm pretty new to linux, and the computer's used by non-tech-savvy people who don't have much patience if I've broken the system and they want to check their email. Know what I mean?
I think I'll leave things as they are if it won't make future problems.
